sections.title: Introduction to Elastic
sections.content:
Elastic is a modern web-based dashboard tool for FRC robots that provides real-time data visualization and robot monitoring. It can run in a browser and connects to your robot over the network, making it accessible from any device on your network. Elastic offers a flexible, customizable interface for displaying sensor data, robot state, and interactive controls.

Elastic is part of the WPILib dashboard ecosystem and provides an alternative to SmartDashboard and Shuffleboard with a modern web-based interface. It's particularly useful for teams that want a browser-based dashboard that can be accessed from multiple devices simultaneously.

Learn more:
WPILib Documentation: Elastic
Official Elastic Documentation

sections.title: What Elastic Provides
sections.subtitle: Elastic allows you to:
items: Display sensor values and robot state in real-time via web browser
Create custom dashboard layouts with drag-and-drop widgets
Monitor motor speeds, currents, and temperatures
View robot pose and position on field visualization
Plot data over time with interactive graphs
Access dashboard from multiple devices simultaneously
Create responsive layouts that work on different screen sizes
Use modern web technologies for better performance

sections.title: Installing and Launching Elastic
sections.content:
Elastic is included with WPILib installation. It runs as a web server that you access through your browser.

Installation: Elastic is typically installed automatically with WPILib. If needed, ensure you have the latest WPILib version installed from the WPILib releases page.

Launching Elastic:
1. Ensure your robot code is running and connected to the network
2. Elastic runs automatically when your robot code starts (if configured)
3. Open a web browser on any device connected to the same network
4. Navigate to https://gold872.github.io/elastic-dashboard/ or open the desktop app on your computer.

Team Number Configuration: Elastic uses your team number to determine the robot's IP address. Make sure your robot's team number is configured correctly in your project settings.

sections.title: Elastic Interface Overview
sections.content:
Elastic provides a modern web-based interface that you access through any web browser. The interface is responsive and works on desktops, tablets, and mobile devices.

Main Components:
-
- Dashboard Canvas: Main area where widgets are placed and arranged
- Widget Library: Sidebar or menu with available widget types
- Configuration Panel: Settings and properties for selected widgets
- Toolbar: Tools for adding, removing, and arranging widgets

Widget Types: Elastic provides various widget types:
- Basic: Number, String, Boolean, Text displays
- Charts: Line charts, bar charts, gauge displays
- Field Visualization: 2D field view with robot pose
- Controls: Buttons, sliders, input fields
- Media: Camera streams, image displays

Layout Management: You can create multiple dashboard tabs, save layouts, and customize the interface to match your team's needs.

sections.title: Displaying Data from Robot Code
sections.content:
To display data in Elastic, you use NetworkTables to send data from your robot code. NetworkTables is the underlying communication protocol that Elastic uses to receive data from your robot.

Using NetworkTables:
Elastic automatically receives data published to NetworkTables. You can use the NetworkTables API or the SmartDashboard compatibility layer to send data. I would recommend using the SmartDashboard compatibility layer, as it is easier to use and more familiar to most people.

Learn more: WPILib Documentation: Elastic Dashboard

sections.title: Sending Data to Elastic Via SmartDashboard
Adding and Customizing Widgets
sections.content:
Widgets are the cards on the dashboard grid that display information about your robot. Elastic makes it easy to add and customize widgets to create a dashboard that fits your needs.

Adding Widgets:
1. Click the "Add Widget" button with a + icon in the menu bar at the top of the screen
2. The widget dialog will open showing all available data from NetworkTables
3. Click on table names to reveal sub-tables and find the data you want to display
4. Use the search box at the bottom of the dialog to quickly find specific values
5. Click and drag the data value to the location on the grid where you want the widget
6. A red or green outline will indicate whether the location is valid
7. Release the mouse to place the widget

Resizing Widgets: After placing a widget, you can resize it by dragging the edges of the widget's box.

Customizing Widgets: Right-click on any widget to open a context menu with options to "Edit Properties" or "Remove". The Edit Properties menu allows you to:
- Change the widget title and type
- Adjust container settings
- Modify NetworkTables settings (advanced)
- Configure widget-specific properties depending on the widget type

Copying and Pasting Widgets: You can copy widgets by right-clicking and selecting "Copy". Then right-click in an empty spot to paste the widget, which will place it at that location if there's enough space.

Camera Streams: To add camera streams, your robot code must publish them to the RoboRIO's Camera Server. Add CameraServer.startAutomaticCapture(); in your robotInit() method, then navigate to the CameraPublisher table in the widget dialog to add camera stream widgets.

sections.title: Interactive Controls and Reading Values
sections.content:
Elastic allows you to create interactive controls (buttons, sliders, input fields) that your robot code can read in real-time. This is useful for tuning parameters, triggering actions, and testing without physical controls.

Reading Widget Values: Your robot code can read values from Elastic widgets using NetworkTables. You can use either the NetworkTables API directly or the SmartDashboard compatibility layer, which is recommended for simplicity.

SmartDashboard Methods: The easiest way to read values is using SmartDashboard.get methods:
- SmartDashboard.getNumber("key", defaultValue) - Read a number
- SmartDashboard.getString("key", defaultValue) - Read text
- SmartDashboard.getBoolean("key", defaultValue) - Read true/false

Creating Interactive Controls: Add button or slider widgets in Elastic and configure them to write to NetworkTables keys. Your robot code then reads these keys using SmartDashboard.get methods to respond to user input. This allows you to create tuning interfaces, test modes, and interactive debugging tools.

For detailed instructions on adding widgets, customizing properties, and advanced features, please refer to the Elastic Documentation: Adding and Customizing Widgets.

Advanced Widget Types
sections.content:
Elastic provides advanced widgets for complex data visualization and robot monitoring.

Chart Widgets: Create line charts, bar charts, and gauge displays to visualize data over time. Useful for monitoring sensor readings, motor performance, or PID tuning.

Field Visualization: Display a 2D visualization of the game field with your robot's position and orientation. Requires pose estimation (odometry) in your robot code. Extremely useful for autonomous development and debugging.

Command and Subsystem Widgets: Show the status of commands and subsystems in command-based programming. Displays which commands are running, scheduled, or interrupted, and subsystem states.

Camera Stream Widgets: Display video feeds from cameras connected to the robot. Useful for driver vision and autonomous navigation.

Custom Widgets: Elastic supports custom widget development, allowing teams to create specialized visualizations for their specific needs.

sections.title: Field Visualization with Elastic
sections.content:
Elastic's Field widget displays a 2D visualization of the game field with your robot's position. This is extremely useful for autonomous development and debugging.

Setting Up Field Visualization:
1. Add a Field widget to your Elastic dashboard
2. Configure it with the current game field image
3. Your robot code sends pose data (x, y, rotation) to NetworkTables
4. The widget displays robot position in real-time

In Robot Code: Use Field2d class to send pose data to NetworkTables. This requires pose estimation (odometry) in your robot code. The Field2d object publishes to NetworkTables automatically.

Multi-Device Access
sections.content:
One of Elastic's key advantages is that multiple devices can access the dashboard simultaneously. This is useful for teams where multiple people need to monitor the robot.

Accessing from Multiple Devices:
- Open a web browser on any device connected to the same network
- Navigate to https://gold872.github.io/elastic-dashboard/
- Each device gets its own view of the dashboard
- Changes to the dashboard layout are typically per-device (browser-based)

Use Cases:
- Driver and operator can each have their own dashboard view
- Programming team can monitor robot during testing
- Strategy team can view robot state during matches
- Multiple team members can debug simultaneously

Network Considerations: Ensure your network can handle multiple connections. Elastic is designed to be efficient, but very high update rates from multiple devices may impact network performance.

sections.title: Performance Considerations
sections.content:
Elastic sends data over the network using NetworkTables, so efficient data management is important for good performance.

Network Bandwidth: Each dashboard update uses network bandwidth. Too many updates or too much data can slow down robot communication. Use reasonable update frequencies.

Update Frequency: Most data doesn't need to update every cycle. Update at reasonable rates (5-20 Hz) depending on the data type. Critical data can update more frequently, while status information can update less frequently.

Data Amount: Sending large amounts of data (like high-resolution images or large arrays) can be slow. Use efficient data types and only send what's necessary for the dashboard.
